description: From Middle English straw, from Old English strēaw, from Proto-West Germanic *strau, from Proto-Germanic *strawą (“that which is strewn”). Cognate with Dutch stro, Walloon strin, German Stroh, Norwegian and Swedish strå, Albanian shtrohë (“kennel”).

entries.meaning: Of a pale, yellowish beige colour, like that of a dried straw.

examples: A straw enemy built up in the media to seem like a real threat, which then collapses like a balloon.

entries.meaning: (countable) A dried stalk of a cereal plant.

(uncountable) Such dried stalks considered collectively; this bulk matter may be a chief salable product, a by-product, fodder, bedding, or green manure, depending on region and on current market conditions.
examples: Coordinate terms: hay, stover, shaw, trash

entries.meaning: (uncommon) A pale, yellowish beige colour, like that of a dried straw.
(figurative) Anything proverbially worthless; the least possible thing.
examples: ‘For thy sword and thy bow I care not a straw,Nor all thine arrows to boot;If I get a knop upon thy bare scop,Thou canst as well shite as shoote.’

verbs.description: straw (third-person singular simple present straws, present participle strawing, simple past and past participle strawed)

entries.meaning: To lay straw around plants to protect them from frost.
(obsolete, slang) To sell straws on the streets in order to cover the giving to the purchaser of things usually banned, such as pornography.
